Context:
Three-year advanced diploma program in Electromechanical Engineering Technology specializing in Building Automation. Graduates will learn to install, program, adjust, and maintain building automation systems. They will also collect data for use in real-time or archiving in a central server, work with building software platforms, and gain skills for "green" careers focused on energy efficiency and sustainability.

Industry Skills:
- Safety practices in the installation and troubleshooting of HVAC/R systems according to codes and standards of NEC, ASHRAE, OSHA, EPA, etc.
- Basic HVAC/R processes and operation of commercial HVAC/R systems.
- Control loops and control modes in digital, analog, and pneumatic commercial control systems.
- Reading blueprints and manufacturer’s technical instructions for installing or servicing sensors, controllers, actuators, and related relays and power supplies.
- General-purpose software and specific building automation software for monitoring and controlling HVAC/R and electrical systems.
- Various BAS controls and systems including DCS, PLC, PAC, and SCADA.
- Functions of network devices and protocols like a bridge, router, gateway, hub, firewall, twisted pair, Ethernet, TCP/IP, Zigbee, WiFi, BAS/IP, and BACnet.
- Emerging green technologies such as solar, wind, and hydronic, and their integration into building systems and residential applications.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Electromechanical Engineering Technology – Building Automation Program T171 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a building automation program offered by the college. After graduating from this program, one can work in various industries such as electronics companies, general contractors, communication and information systems companies, lighting suppliers and contractors, mechanical and electronic controller manufacturers, facilities management companies, autonomous vehicles and robotics companies, residential developers, etc.

The program consists of six semesters. In the first semester, students take courses like Circuit Analysis, Mechanical Engineering Design, Machining Fundamentals and Metrology, Occupational Health and Safety, Personal Finance, Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1, Communicating Across Contexts, etc.

In the second semester, students study Engineering Physics, Electronic Devices, Electro-Pneumatics, Electrical Techniques, Mathematics for Engineering Technology 2, General Education elective, Introduction to PLC Systems, Digital Electronics, Operations Management & Quality Control, and Sensors and Instrumentation.

In the third semester, students learn about Introduction to PLC Systems, Digital Electronics, Operations Management & Quality Control, Sensors and Instrumentation, Automation Software Development, Blueprint Reading for Buildings, and a General Education elective.

In the fourth semester, students take courses like Instrumentation 2, Internet of Things for Homes, Network Fundamentals, Advanced PLC Systems, Sustainable Energy Technologies, and Thermodynamics.

In the fifth semester, students study Applied Project 1, Building Science Fundamentals, Building Networks and Protocols, Alarm and Video Systems, Building Control Systems, and Fundamentals of HVAC/R Systems.

Finally, in the sixth semester, students learn about various topics like Applied Project 2, and specific courses are not mentioned in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Electromechanical Engineering Technology – Building Automation Program T171 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
SEMESTER 6 Courses:
- EMNG 2040: Workplace Preparedness and Technical Writing
- EMNG 3011: Building Management and Commissioning
- EMNG 3013: Building Sub-Systems and Integration
- EMNG 3018: Applied Project 2
- EMNG 3019: Building Operations and Management
- EMNG 3021: Connected Homes

You may need to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000.

General Education Electives.

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate has reliably demonstrated the ability to:
1. Fabricate and build electrical, electronic and mechanical components and assemblies in accordance with operating standards, job requirements and specifications.
2. Analyze, interpret and produce electrical, electronic and mechanical drawings and other related technical documents and graphics necessary for electromechanical design in compliance with industry standards.
3. Select and use a variety of troubleshooting techniques and equipment to assess, modify, maintain and repair electromechanical circuits, equipment, processes, systems and subsystems.
4. Modify, maintain, and repair electrical, electronic and mechanical components, equipment, and systems to ensure that they function according to specifications and to optimize production.
5. Design and analyze mechanical components, processes and systems by applying engineering principles and practices.
6. Design, analyze, build, select, commission, integrate and troubleshoot a variety of industrial motor controls and data acquisition devices and systems, digital circuits, passive AC and DC circuits, active circuits and microprocessor-based systems.
7. Install and troubleshoot computer hardware and programming to support the electromechanical engineering environment.
8. Analyze, program, install, integrate, troubleshoot and diagnose automated systems including robotic systems.
9. Establish and maintain inventory, records and documentation systems to meet organizational and industry standards and requirements.
10. Select and purchase electromechanical equipment, components and systems that fulfill job requirements and functional specifications.
11. Specify, coordinate and apply quality-control and quality-assurance programs and procedures to meet organizational standards and requirements.
12. Work in compliance with relevant industry standards, laws and regulations, codes, policies and procedures.
13. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance and to remain current in the field and responsive to emergent technologies and national and international standards.

Context:
The text provides information about a program offered at George Brown College, specifically an electromechanical engineering program. Here are some factual extracts from the text:

1. The program aims for students to perform well and stay updated in their field while responding to emerging technologies and national/international standards.
2. Students contribute as individuals and team members to complete tasks and projects effectively.
3. They design and analyze electromechanical systems by interpreting fluid mechanics and understanding hydraulic and fluid power systems.
4. Students can contribute to project management by planning, implementing, and evaluating projects, while monitoring resources, timelines, and expenditures as needed.
5. Estimated tuition fees for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2023: $4,312.00 (Domestic) and $18,361.00 (International).
6. Students are responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if required.
7. The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
8. Applicants must have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 Math (C or U). Mature students may apply without an OSSD but must meet other criteria.
9. The information on the website is subject to change without notice, and applicants should verify George Brown College fee requirements.

Context:
Applicants who are 19 years of age or older and do not have an OSSD can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or upgrade to achieve the required credits in English and Math. Mature students may need grades higher than the minimum requirements for admission. Course exemptions can be achieved through college or university credits, more information can be found on the Transfer Guide.

International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.

Contact information for the School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 4365, Email: engineeringtech@georgebrown.ca, Office hours: 8 a.m. – 4 p.m., room D305. George Brown College can also be contacted through the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. International students can contact recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through the International Contact Us page.

Campus tours and information sessions can be booked on the website, and applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process. Programs offered include Electromechanical Engineering Technician (T146), Mechanical Engineering Technology – Design (T121), and Electrical Techniques (T167).

Applicants can apply through Ontario Colleges, international students through the George Brown College Online Application System. Applicants must have JavaScript enabled to use the application form and provide their first name, last name, email, domestic or international status, and country.
